subject: Law
title: Citizens United and Campaign Finance
description: A 60-second lesson on Citizens United and Campaign Finance.

hook.text: In 2010, the Supreme Court ruled that corporations can spend unlimited money on elections. The backlash was instant.

buildup.text: Citizens United v. FEC held that political spending is protected free speech under the First Amendment.

discovery.text: The ruling struck down limits on independent expenditures by corporations and unions during elections.

twist.text: Super PACs emerged, spending billions. Critics say it legalized corruption; supporters call it free expression.

climax.text: Campaign spending has skyrocketed since 2010. The 2020 election cycle exceeded $14 billion.

punchline.text: Money talks. Citizens United made sure the law listens.

quiz.question: What did Citizens United v. FEC rule about corporate political spending?
options: It's protected free speech under the First Amendment
It must be publicly disclosed only
